query: Please help me summarize this government report.
gt:
House rules govern the length of time legislative measures must be available to Members before being considered on the floor. For measures reported from committee, a draft of the committee report must have been available for 72 hours. Conference reports must also have been available for 72 hours and special rules for considering measures for one legislative day. Bills and joint resolutions that have not been reported by committee, and therefore are not accompanied by a written report, may also not be considered on the House floor unless the measure has been available for 72 hours. Proposed committee reports, unreported bills and joint resolutions, conference reports, and joint explanatory statements are considered available under these rules if they are publicly available in electronic form on a website designated by the Committee on House Administration for this purpose, http://docs.house.gov.
The House has several means by which it can choose to waive these availability requirements and call up, debate, and vote on a measure in a single calendar day even if the text of the measure was not made available prior to consideration. These include (1) considering a measure under the suspension of the rules procedure or by unanimous consent, (2) adopting a special rule that waives the 72-hour requirement, (3) adopting a special rule that waives the one-day requirement for another special rule, and (4) convening a second legislative day on the same calendar day. Waiving availability requirements allows the House to act quickly when necessary, such as near the end of a session.

gpt4-x_pred:
This government report discusses the availability requirements in the House Rules for legislative measures, including reported bills and resolutions, unreported bills and joint resolutions, conference committee reports, and special rules. The House Rules ensure that Members have an opportunity to review legislative measures by governing the length of time they must be made available before being considered on the floor.

Reported bills and resolutions require a draft of the committee report to be available for at least 72 hours before consideration on the House floor. Unreported bills and joint resolutions also require a 72-hour availability period. Conference reports must be available in the Congressional Record for 72 hours or publicly available in electronic form at a designated location. Special rules, which can waive any or all of the above rules, must lie over for one legislative day before being considered.

The House has several means for waiving its rules when it wishes to act expeditiously, such as unanimous consent, a two-thirds vote to suspend the rules, or waiving the availability requirements by a simple majority through special rules. The House can also convene for two legislative days on the same calendar day to waive the one-day layover requirement for special rules.

Near the end of a session, the Rules Committee may report several special rules that waive the availability requirements for subsequent special rules for the consideration of certain specified measures. These special rules, sometimes referred to as "same day rules" or "martial law" rules, allow the House to achieve the same end as the standing rules that waive availability requirements at the end of a session.

query: Please generate the Abstract section for this paper.
gt: Simultaneous machine translation models start generating a target sequence before they have encoded the source sequence. Recent approaches for this task either apply a fixed policy on a state-of-the art Transformer model, or a learnable monotonic attention on a weaker recurrent neural network-based structure. In this paper, we propose a new attention mechanism, Monotonic Multihead Attention (MMA), which extends the monotonic attention mechanism to multihead attention. We also introduce two novel and interpretable approaches for latency control that are specifically designed for multiple attention heads. We apply MMA to the simultaneous machine translation task and demonstrate better latency-quality tradeoffs compared to MILk, the previous state-of-the-art approach. We analyze how the latency controls affect the attention span and we study the relationship between the speed of a head and the layer it belongs to. Finally, we motivate the introduction of our model by analyzing the effect of the number of decoder layers and heads on quality and latency.

gpt4-x_pred: In this paper, the authors propose two variants of Monotonic Multihead Attention (MMA) for simultaneous machine translation, aiming to achieve better quality-latency trade-offs than the previous state-of-the-art model. The two variants, Hard MMA (MMA-H) and Infinite Lookback MMA (MMA-IL), combine the high translation quality of multilayer multihead attention with the low latency of monotonic attention. The authors also introduce two novel latency regularization methods to control the model's speed and prevent latency from being dominated by a single or a few heads. The proposed MMA model outperforms existing monotonic attention mechanisms on two standard translation benchmarks, IWSLT15 English-Vietnamese (En-Vi) and WMT15 German-English (De-En). The paper also presents detailed ablation studies and analyses on the effect of the number of decoder layers and decoder heads, attention span, attention behaviors, and the rank of the heads. The proposed simultaneous sequence-to-sequence models have the potential to facilitate important applications, such as high-quality real-time interpretation between human speakers.

gt: Recent work on simultaneous machine translation falls into three categories. In the first one, models use a rule-based policy for reading input and writing output. Cho & Esipova (2016) propose a WaitIf-* policy to enable an offline model to decode simultaneously. Ma et al. (2019) propose a wait-k policy where the model first reads k tokens, then alternates between read and write actions. Dalvi et al. (2018) propose an incremental decoding method, also based on a rule-based schedule. In the second category, a flexible policy is learnt from data. Grissom II et al. (2014) introduce a Markov chain to phrase-based machine translation models for simultaneous machine translation, in which they apply reinforcement learning to learn the read-write policy based on states. Gu et al. (2017) introduce an agent which learns to make decisions on when to translate from the interaction with a pre-trained offline neural machine translation model. Luo et al. (2017) used continuous rewards policy gradient for online alignments for speech recognition. Lawson et al.

gpt4-x_pred:
Related Work

The development of simultaneous machine translation models has been an active area of research in recent years. Dalvi et al. (2018) proposed incremental decoding and training methods for simultaneous translation in neural machine translation, which aimed to improve the efficiency of the translation process. Grissom et al. (2014) introduced a reinforcement learning approach for simultaneous machine translation, focusing on not waiting until the final verb to generate translations. This work demonstrated the potential of reinforcement learning in addressing the challenges of simultaneous translation.

Gu et al. (2017) presented a method for learning to translate in real-time with neural machine translation, which aimed to balance translation quality and latency. Lawson et al. (2018) explored learning hard alignments with variational inference, providing a novel approach to handling the alignment problem in simultaneous translation. Luo et al. (2017) proposed learning online alignments with continuous rewards policy gradient, further demonstrating the potential of reinforcement learning techniques in this domain.

More recently, Ma et al. (2019) introduced STACL, a simultaneous translation model with implicit anticipation and controllable latency using a prefix-to-prefix framework. This work showcased the benefits of incorporating anticipation and latency control mechanisms in simultaneous translation models. Our proposed monotonic multihead attention model builds upon these previous works, leveraging the power of the Transformer architecture to achieve better quality-latency trade-offs in simultaneous machine translation.

query: Please write a review for this paper and you should provide some suggestions and raise some questions in your review.
gt:
This paper proposes a fully transformer-based monotonic attention framework that extends the idea of MILK. Though the idea of monotonic multi-head attention sounds interesting, I still have some questions below:

About the method:
   1. Is that possible that the MMA would have worse latency than MILK since all the attention heads need to agree to write while MILK only has one attention head?
   2. Is there any attention order between different attention head?
   3. I think the MMA only could control the latency during training time, which would produce different models with different latency. Is there any way that enables MMA to control the latency during inference time? Can we change the latency for on given model by tuning the requirements mentioned in Eq. (1)?

About the experiments:
    1. Do you have any explanation of why both MMA-H and MMA-IL have better BLEU when AL is small? The results in fig 2 seem counterintuitive. 
    2. I suggest the authors do more analysis of the difference between different attention heads to prove the effectiveness of MMA. 
    3. For the left two figures in fig 4, which one is the baseline, and which one is the proposed model?

I also suggest the authors present more real sample analysis and discussions about the experiments.
6: Weak Accept

In this paper, the authors propose two variants of monotonic multihead attention (MMA) models for simultaneous machine translation, namely MMA-H(ard) and MMA-IL(infinite lookback). These models aim to combine the high translation quality of the Transformer architecture with the low latency of monotonic attention mechanisms. The authors also introduce two novel latency regularization methods to control latency and attention span effectively.

The paper is well-structured and provides a comprehensive overview of the proposed models, their implementation, and experimental setup. The results demonstrate that the proposed MMA models achieve better quality-latency trade-offs than the previous state-of-the-art model, MILk. The authors also present detailed ablation studies and analyses to support their claims.

However, there are a few points that could be further clarified or explored in the paper:

1. The authors could provide more insights into the choice of hyperparameters for the latency regularization methods and their impact on the model's performance.

2. It would be interesting to see how the proposed MMA models perform on other language pairs and datasets, as well as in other sequence-to-sequence tasks, such as speech recognition or summarization.

3. The authors mention that the MMA-H model is better suited for streaming systems with stricter efficiency requirements. It would be helpful to provide a more detailed comparison between the two proposed models in terms of their applicability to different real-world scenarios.

Overall, this paper presents a promising approach to simultaneous machine translation by leveraging the power of the Transformer architecture and monotonic attention mechanisms. The proposed models and regularization methods show potential for further exploration and application in various sequence-to-sequence tasks.

query: Please generate the Abstract section for this paper.
gt: Deep neural networks have achieved outstanding performance in many real-world applications with the expense of huge computational resources. The DenseNet, one of the recently proposed neural network architecture, has achieved the state-of-the-art performance in many visual tasks. However, it has great redundancy due to the dense connections of the internal structure, which leads to high computational costs in training such dense networks. To address this issue, we design a reinforcement learning framework to search for efficient DenseNet architectures with layer-wise pruning (LWP) for different tasks, while retaining the original advantages of DenseNet, such as feature reuse, short paths, etc. In this framework, an agent evaluates the importance of each connection between any two block layers, and prunes the redundant connections. In addition, a novel reward-shaping trick is introduced to make DenseNet reach a better trade-off between accuracy and float point operations (FLOPs). Our experiments show that DenseNet with LWP is more compact and efficient than existing alternatives.

query: Please write a review for this paper and you should provide some suggestions and raise some questions in your review.
gt:
The paper introduces RL based approach to prune layers in a DenseNet. This work extends BlockDrop to DenseNet architecture making the controller independent form the input image. The approach is evaluated on CIFAR10 and CIFAR100 datasets as well as on ImageNet showing promising results.

In order to improve the paper, the authors could take into consideration the following points:
1. Given the similarity of the approach with BlockDrop, I would suggest to discuss it in the introduction section clearly stating the similarities and the differences with the proposed approach. 
2. BlockDrop seems to introduce a general framework of policy network to prune neural networks. However, the authors claim that BlockDrop "can only be applied to ResNets or its variants". Could the authors comment on this? 
3. In the abstract, the authors claim: "Our experiments show that DenseNet with LWP is more compact and efficient than existing alternatives". It is hard to asses if the statement is correct given the evidence presented in the experimental section. It is not clear if the method is more efficient and compact than others, e. g.  CondenseNet. 
4. In the experimental section, addressing the following questions would make the section stronger: What is more important FLOPs or number of parameters? What is the accuracy drop we should allow to pay for reduction in number of parameters or FLOPs?
5. For the evaluation, I would suggest to show that the learned policy is better than a random one: e. g. not using the controller to define policy (in line 20 of the algorithm) and using a random random policy instead.
6. In Table 1, some entries for DenseNet LWP are missing. Is the network converging for this setups? 
7. \sigma is not explained in section 3.3. What is the intuition behind this hyper parameter?


Additional comments:
1. It might be interesting to compare the method introduced in the paper to a scenario where the controller is conditioned on an input image and adaptively selects the connections/layers in DenseNet at inference time.
2. It might be interesting to report the number of connections in Table 1 for all the models.

Title: Layer-wise Pruning for DenseNet with Reinforcement Learning

Review:

This paper presents a layer-wise pruning method for DenseNet based on reinforcement learning. The authors propose an LSTM controller to generate inference paths and a reward shaping technique to guide the pruning process. The method is evaluated on CIFAR-10, CIFAR-100, and ImageNet datasets, showing significant reductions in the number of parameters and FLOPs while maintaining or slightly degrading the prediction performance.

The paper is well-written and provides a clear explanation of the proposed method. The authors have done a good job of explaining the motivation behind their work and the challenges they aim to address. The method is based on a solid foundation of reinforcement learning and policy gradient, and the authors provide a thorough background on these topics.

The experimental results are impressive, showing that the proposed method can achieve significant compression and acceleration of DenseNet while maintaining competitive performance. The authors also provide a detailed analysis of the child networks and the filter parameters in every convolution layer, which helps to demonstrate the effectiveness of their method.

However, there are a few areas where the paper could be improved:

1. The authors should provide more details on the choice of hyperparameters, such as the exponential power α and the penalty γ. While they do provide some analysis in the appendix, it would be helpful to include more information on how these hyperparameters were chosen and how they affect the performance of the method.

2. The paper could benefit from a more thorough comparison with other pruning methods, such as parameter pruning and sharing, low-rank factorization, and knowledge distillation. While the authors do mention these methods briefly, a more detailed comparison would help to demonstrate the advantages of their approach.

3. The authors should consider providing more details on the training configurations for the CIFAR and ImageNet experiments, such as the learning rate schedules and the choice of optimizers. This information would be helpful for readers who wish to reproduce the results or compare the method with other approaches.

4. It would be interesting to see how the proposed method performs on other types of neural networks, such as ResNet or MobileNet. This would help to demonstrate the generalizability of the approach and its potential applicability to a wider range of network architectures.

In conclusion, this paper presents a promising method for layer-wise pruning of DenseNet using reinforcement learning. The experimental results are impressive, and the authors provide a thorough analysis of the method's effectiveness. However, the paper could be improved by providing more details on the choice of hyperparameters, a more thorough comparison with other pruning methods, and an evaluation of the method's performance on other types of neural networks.

query: Write a summary for the scene.
gt: It's the first day of school at Degrassi Community School, and eighth-grader Ashley already has her sights set on becoming the school's newest student council president. Her seemingly sure win is soon threatened when her stepbrother, Toby, becomes frustrated by her unchallenged status and convinces his friend J.T. to run against her. Meanwhile, Emma and Manny deal with eighth-grader Spinner's bullying. Note: This episode marks the first appearances of Sarah Barrable-Tishauer, Lauren Collins, Aubrey Graham, and Shane Kippel as Liberty Van Zandt, Paige Michalchuk, Jimmy Brooks, and Spinner Mason.
